Covid severity much lower in Gauteng
item.description:
Scott Gottlieb, MD on Twitter

“New preprint on Covid impact in Gauteng. During #Omicron wave 17.68% of all recorded hospital admissions were children and teens under 20 years, vs 3.97% during second wave, 3.52% during third (Delta) wave. 5.8% of children and teens are vaxxed in Gauteng https://t.co/UhX1QyK1UU”

URL: https://twitter.com/ScottGottliebMD/status/1476581879524564995

source: Thursday assorted links

item.title: 1/4 of the death rate from Delta there
item.description:
Andrew Lilley on Twitter

“The most important question for capacity to handle the Omicron wave is the progression of cases from hospitalised to ICU and death. In South Africa the progression from hospitalised to ICU and death for Omicron was 20%-25% of the rate of Delta. Preprint: https://t.co/3l1yxpURqR”

URL: https://twitter.com/andrewlilley_au/status/1476581027938140162

item.title: Ending Safety as a Writer and a Reader
item.description:
When I started The End of Safety, I was hoping to name it based on some phrase in James Baldwin’s great essay, “The White Man’s Guilt.” The first time I read that essay, and every time since, I have been drawn to Baldwin’s description of “those who imagine that history flatters them” as being “impaled on their history like a butterfly on a pin” thereby …

USSR 1922-1991, USA 1776-2025?
item.description:
Thirty years ago today the Soviet Union came to an end. This is not an occasion for triumphalism. It is a warning. Stagnation, or the absence of a future, was the underlying Soviet problem. Stalinism had created temporary social mobility in the Soviet Union, if at the cost of millions of deaths and the creation of the largest prison system in the world…

URL: https://snyder.substack.com/p/ussr-1922-1991-usa-1776-2025?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

item.title: How do we study the severity of a new variant?
item.description:
Want to better understand the research coming out on the severity of Omicron? This is my guide to help you organize your thinking. Consider it a companion to the emerging research, with an emphasis on intuition rather than numbers. We can think about an individual’s risk of severe disease as reflecting three components: (1) their risk of exposure, (2) th…

URL: https://nataliexdean.substack.com/p/how-do-we-study-the-severity-of-a?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: GET VACCINATED & BOOSTED!

item.title: Notes on a Remarkable Finding from Finland
item.description:
I recently came across a paper by Ursina Schaede and Ville Mankki that contains a fascinating empirical finding with major implications for the way in which we think about meritocracy. The paper examines the long run effects on students of a change in the manner in which their teachers were selected into a graduate program. Finland is well known for hav…

URL: https://rajivsethi.substack.com/p/notes-on-a-remarkable-finding-from?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Against Meritocracy
